G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28 – Authorizes modification of custody orders when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the children’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: G.L. c. 209C, § 20 – Governs custody modification for children of unmarried parents.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) – Reinforces that a custody modification must be grounded in a material and substantial change in circumstances.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion in Hunter v. Rose is a first-instance custody determination between two legal parents after dissolution of their California registered domestic partnership. The court articulates and applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, not the standard for modifying a prior custody order. There is no discussion of a requirement of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ as a predicate for modifying an existing custody arrangement, so the case does not reinforce that modification standard.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ … ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge….’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494–495).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) – Provides that the children’s best interests are the paramount consideration in custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that in removal/custody matters “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and interprets the governing statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests. Although the case focuses on relocation by a custodial parent, its reasoning clearly affirms that best interests of the child are the controlling standard in such custody-related determinations, which matches the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child…”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) – Recognizes that interference with a parent’s relationship with the children may constitute grounds for modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the governing standard for custody determinations—best interests/welfare of the child—and rejects using custody as a means to discipline a parent. It does not discuss interference with the other parent’s relationship with the children or identify such interference as a ground for modifying custody. The case is about the need for proper findings on comparative parental environments, not about interference as a basis for modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’… ‘Custody is not a prize . . . .’ On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) – Prohibits one parent from making unilateral decisions that affect the other parent’s rights.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case concerns a primary custodial parent’s request to relocate and the standards for modifying custody and permitting removal under Massachusetts law. It does not address, establish, or discuss any rule about one parent being prohibited from making unilateral decisions that affect the other parent’s rights. The holding focuses on the need for a material and substantial change in circumstances for custody modification and the ‘real advantage’ test for relocation, not on unilateral decision-making between parents.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) – Reiterates the importance of children’s emotional stability in custody decisions.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the removal question in terms of the children’s ‘best interests’ and applies that standard by focusing heavily on the children’s developmental, social, and emotional well‑being, including the impact of parental conflict and instability. In particular, the court notes that the conflict and allegations between the parents left the child feeling ‘scared’ and ‘emotionally harmed,’ and treats these emotional effects, along with disruption of their current supports, as central to the custody/removal analysis. This supports the proposition that children’s emotional stability is an important factor in such decisions.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The judge found that the mother’s children claimed one of them was inappropriately touched by the son of the mother’s new husband. … This tension left the child, who subsequently recanted and then reasserted his claim of abuse, feeling ‘scared about his role in the family’ and ‘emotionally harmed’ by his parents’ ongoing conflict.”

Stone v. Duffy, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 803 (2.raw_text: Stone v. Duffy, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 803 (2021)
Stone v. Duffy, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 803 (2.proposition: Stone v. Duffy, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 803 (2021) – Discusses the importance of the court’s role in ensuring compliance with custody orders.

Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918.raw_text: Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918 (1996)
Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918.proposition: Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918 (1996) – Highlights that disparaging a parent in front of the children may merit legal intervention.
Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Galper v. Galper and does not concern family law, parenting, or disparagement of a parent before children. It addresses a firefighter’s right to paid leave and related benefits under Massachusetts statutes. Because it never discusses parental behavior, disparagement, or legal intervention in custody/visitation based on such conduct, it does not support the stated proposition.
Galper v. Galper, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 918.relevant_excerpt: We see nothing in the circumstances of this case to put it outside the holding of Paparo v. Provincetown, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 625, 628 (1993), and cases therein cited, that “absent some overriding disqualification such as waiver, forfeiture, pension, retirement, or termination of incapacity, rights to disability benefits, once accrued to the benefit of the disabled officer, cannot be cut off by the expiration of the period of employment.”

\u00a7 31A of the Massachusetts Parentin.proposition: § 31A of the Massachusetts Parenting Act – Promotes frequent and continuing contact with both parents, balanced by the requirement to protect the children’s emotional wellbeing.
